titleStmt.title: Managing Multigranular Unbalanced Hesitant Fuzzy Linguistic Information in Multiattribute Large-Scale Group Decision Making: A Linguistic Distribution-Based Approach

analytic.title: Managing Multigranular Unbalanced Hesitant Fuzzy Linguistic Information in Multiattribute Large-Scale Group Decision Making: A Linguistic Distribution-Based Approach

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: With the increase of technological and societal demands, more and more decision makers are involved in the process of group decision making which is called large-scale group decision making (LGDM). For an LGDM problem with linguistic information, it is common that different decision makers tend to provide linguistic assessments defined on multigranular linguistic term sets due to the difference in knowledge and culture background and that hesitant fuzzy linguistic term sets (HFLTSs) are used by decision makers to model the hesitancy of their assessments. This paper proposes first an algorithm to represent a linguistic distribution assessment (LDA) using a hesitant linguistic distribution (HLD). Two other algorithms are then proposed to transform an unbalanced HFLTS into a balanced LDA and to transform a balanced LDA into an unbalanced LDA, respectively. An approach is then proposed to deal with multiattribute LGDM problems with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information based on these algorithms. In the proposed approach, all unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is transformed into LDAs defined on a balanced linguistic term set and then an LDA-based clustering algorithm is devised to cluster decision makers. Based on the clustering result, decision makers' linguistic distribution decision matrices are further fused to obtain collective assessments of alternatives. In order to provide linguistic results easy to understand for decision makers, all LDAs of alternatives are represented by HLDs defined on each decision maker's initial linguistic term set. Finally, an example for the selection of subway lines is used to demonstrate the proposed approach.

G Roup decision making (GDM) is a process during which a group of decision makers express their assessments over alternatives to obtain a final solution of a decision making problem [1]. The resolution of a typical GDM problem usually involves two processes, i.e., the consensus process and the selection process [2]. The consensus process aims to help decision makers achieve a satisfactory level of agreement about their assessments over alternatives, while the selection process is achieved by fusing different decision makers' opinions to obtain a collective assessment of alternatives and hence a ranking of alternatives. In the literature, different proposals have been devoted to the studies of consensus process and selection process in GDM [3]- [6].

For classical GDM problems, it is usually assumed that only a small group of decision makers is involved in the decision making process. With the increase of technological development and societal demands, such as social networks, egroup shopping and e-democracy, more and more individuals can take part in the decision making process [7], [8], which makes GDM activities become more and more complex due to the large group of decision makers and the individual differences among decision makers in knowledge and culture background. Such GDM problems are usually called largescale GDM (LGDM) problems. Currently, LGDM faces four main trends, including (1) clustering methods in LGDM [9]- [11], (2) consensus reaching processes in LGDM [12]- [17], (3) selection models and methods in LGDM [18]- [20] and (4) LGDM support systems [21], [22].

These studies have significantly advanced the studies of LGDM, among which LGDM with linguistic information has attracted attention from scholars because in linguistic LGDM problems, decision makers usually provide their assessments using linguistic expressions instead of exact numerical numbers due to the fuzziness and impreciseness of their knowledge [23] that is close to real world situations. To achieve the goal of linguistic LGDM, the techniques of computing with words (CW) are usually used to fuse linguistic information [24], [25], including the membership degree-based model [26] , ordinal scale model [27], the 2-tuple linguistic model [28], the type-2 fuzzy set-based model [29] and the numerical scale model [30], to name a few; in which the linguistic 2-tuple model stand out because of its characteristics and computational model [23]. Based on these CW techniques, different models and approaches have been developed to deal with linguistic LGDM problems [16], [18]- [20].
Although previous models and approaches are effective for linguistic LGDM problems, there are still some challenges that need to be tackled.

(1) Most of current linguistic LGDM problems usually assume that decision makers will provide their linguistic assessments using a simple linguistic term. For some complex linguistic LGDM problems with high uncertainty, it is possible that decision makers may need more elaborated expressions when providing their assessments [25]. In this case, hesitant fuzzy linguistic term sets (HFLTSs) [31], which allow decision makers to express linguistic assessments using some consecutive linguistic terms, may be a good choice for modelling such situations [32]. However, in the literature, LGDM problems with HFLTSs have not been extensively studied so far.

(2) Linguistic LGDM problems usually involve a large group of decision makers with different knowledge and backgrounds, which implies that multigranular linguistic information can be used by decision makers. For instance, in practical decision making problems, a decision maker may provide HFLTSs based on a linguistic term set S1 = {s 1 0 : poor, s 1 1 : slightly poor, s 1 2 : fair, s 1 3 : slightly good, s 1 4 : good} and another decision maker may provide HFLTSs using a linguistic term set S 2 = {s 2 0 : very poor, s 2 1 : poor, s 2 2 : slightly poor, s 2 3 : fair, s 2 4 : slightly good, s 2 5 : good, s 2 6 : very good}. In this case, fuzzy granular approaches may be a good choice to manage multigranular linguistic information, such as the linguistic hierarchy model [33], the type-2 fuzzy set based models [34], [35], and ordinal models based on discrete fuzzy numbers [36]. Moreover, in most situations, decision makers tend to use a linguistic term set which is uniformly and symmetrically distributed. However, in some situations, decision makers need to use linguistic term sets that are not uniformly and symmetrically distributed, i.e., the unbalanced linguistic term set [37]- [40]. For instance, in the grading system, the number of linguistic terms on the right of the midterm is larger than that on the left. Although some studies have been conducted to deal with GDM problems with unbalanced HFLTSs [41], [42], there are fewer studies that focus on LGDM with multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs.

(3) In the resolution process of a linguistic LGDM problem, linguistic distribution assessments (LDAs) have been proved as an effective tool to keep the maximum information of decision makers in the initial stages of the decision making process [20], [43], [44]. However, the aggregation of LDAs is also an LDA in which the symbolic proportions of linguistic terms are dispersedly distributed which makes hard to provide interpretable linguistic results to decision makers.

Motivated by these three challenges, the aim of this paper is to develop some novel models and algorithms to manage multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information in LGDM. This research first develops an algorithm to represent an LDA using a hesitant linguistic distribution (HLD) [45], which can provide interpretable results regarding an LDA. To fuse multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information, it is developed two algorithms to transform an unbalanced HFLTS into a balanced LDA and to transform a balanced LDA into an unbalanced LDA, respectively based on the 2-tuple linguistic model [28]. Subsequently, an approach is proposed to deal with multiattribute LGDM problems with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information. In the proposed approach, all multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is transformed into LDAs defined on a balanced linguistic term set and then an LDAbased clustering algorithm is devised to cluster decision makers, based on which the collective assessments of each cluster are calculated. A proportion and normalized accuracy index induced ordered weighted averaging (PA-IOWA) operator is further proposed to fuse each cluster's linguistic distribution decision matrix. The collective assessments of alternatives are obtained by aggregating all attribute values for each alternative. Based on the dominance degree-based ranking method, all alternatives are ranked. Finally, the collective assessments are represented by HLDs defined on each decision maker's initial linguistic term set to provide interpretable results.

This paper contributes the area of CW and GDM from the following aspects. First, we discuss the relationship between an LDA and an HLD, and the relationships among multigranular unbalanced linguistic information and balanced LDAs, and develop some algorithms to achieve the transformation among different formats of linguistic information 1 , which lays a good foundation to manage multigranular linguistic information in practical GDM problems. Second, an approach to LGDM with multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs is developed based on the proposed CW methodology, which can both preserve the maximum information of decision makers and provide interpretable linguistic results by using the HLDs for practical LGDM problems.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II revises some preliminaries related to the topic of this paper. In Section III, an algorithm is proposed to represent an LDA using an HLD. Followed by this, it is proposed two algorithms to achieve the transformation between unbalanced linguistic information and a balanced LDA in Section IV. Subsequently, an approach to multiattribute LGDM with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is developed in Section V and a numerical example is presented to demonstrate the proposed approach in Section VI. Eventually, some conclusions are drawn in Section VII.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In this section, some preliminaries are revised. In subsection II-A, the 2-tuple linguistic representation model is introduced. In subsection II-B, some basic knowledge about unbalanced linguistic term set and numerical scale model is provided. Finally, some related work about HFLTSs, LDAs and HLDs is introduced in subsection II-C.

div.head: A. 2-tuple linguistic model
div.p: Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } denote a linguistic term set with odd cardinality, the element s i of which represents the i-th linguistic term in S, and g+1 is the cardinality of the linguistic term set S. Moreover, for the linguistic term set S, we assume that the midterm representing an assessment of "approximately 0.5", with the rest of the terms being placed uniformly and symmetrically around it. The linguistic term set should satisfy the following characteristics [23]: (1) The set is ordered:s i > s j , if i > j; (2) There is a negation operator: Neg(s i ) = s j , such that j = g -i.
Herrera and Martínez [28] proposed the 2-tuple linguistic representation model based on the concept of symbolic translation, which is defined as follows.

Definition 1. [28] Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set, β ∈ [0, g] be a value representing the result of a symbolic aggregation operation and S = S × [-0.5, 0.5), then the 2-tuple that expresses the equivalent information to β is obtained by
with k = round(β), α = β -k, where round(•) is the usual round operation, s k has the closest index label to β, and α is the value of symbolic translation.

Definition 2. [28] Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set and (s k , α) be a linguistic 2-tuple, there exists a function ∆ -1 , which can transform a linguistic 2-tuple into its equivalent numerical value β ∈ [0, g]. The transformation function is defined as
Based on the above definitions, a linguistic term can be considered as a linguistic 2-tuple by adding the value 0 to it as symbolic translation, i.e. s k ∈ S ⇒ (s k , 0).

div.head: B. Unbalanced linguistic information and numerical scale model
div.p: For actual decision making problems, decision makers may provide linguistic terms from linguistic term sets which are not uniformly and symmetrically distributed, i.e., unbalanced linguistic term set. The modelling of unbalanced linguistic information was initially proposed in [46] and extended by linguistic hierarchies in [37]. Usually, an unbalanced linguistic term set S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } with an odd granularity g+1 has a minimum label, a maximum label and a central label, and the remaining labels are non-uniformly and non-symmetrically distributed around the central one on both left and right lateral sets, where
• S L is called the left lateral set, which contains all the labels less than the central label. • S C is called the central set, which just contains the central label.

• S R is called the right lateral set, which contains all the labels greater than the central label. In [37], it is developed a linguistic computational model to represent the labels of an unbalanced linguistic term set through the levels of a linguistic hierarchy and to compute with words based on the 2-tuple linguistic representation model. Subsequently, different extensions of unbalanced linguistic term sets are proposed, such as the numerical scale model proposed by Dong et al. [30]. In [41], it was also proved the equivalence between the linguistic hierarchy based computational model and the numerical scale model for dealing with unbalanced linguistic information. To make this paper selfcontained, some basic knowledge of numerical scale model is revised as follows. Definition 3. [30] Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set and R be the set of real numbers. The function: N S : S → R is defined as a numerical scale of S, and N S(s i ) is called the numerical scale of s i . Definition 4. [30] Let S, S and N S be defined as before. For each (s i , α) ∈ S, the numerical scale N S is defined by

div.head: C. HFLTS, LDA and HLD
div.p: When providing linguistic assessments over alternatives, decision makers sometimes may have some hesitancy. To model such situations, Rodríguez et al. [31] proposed the concept of HFLTS. Definition 6. [31] Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set. An HFLTS H S on S is an ordered finite subset of consecutive linguistic terms in S.

Remark 1. Later on, Rodríguez et al. [47] proposed the use of HFLTS and context-free grammars to build in a formal way Comparative Linguistic Expressions (CLEs) like at most, at least, between, etc. Such expressions are more flexible than a single linguistic label and closer to the expressions provided by human beings in real world decision problems. These CLEs provide an important improvement regarding flexibility to decision makers when eliciting preferences, together a formalization for generating expressions closer human beings' expressions [25].
Remark 2. Clearly, if S is a balanced linguistic term set, H S is called a balanced HFLTS; if S is an unbalanced linguistic term set, H S is called an unbalanced HFLTS.

For a balanced linguistic term set, Zhang et al. [43] defined the LDA and its expectations. Definition 7. [43] Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } denote a balanced linguistic term set and β t be the symbolic proportion of s t , where s t ∈ S, β t ≥ 0, t = 0, 1, . . . , g and g t=0 β t = 1, then an assessment m = {⟨s t , β t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} is called a balanced LDA of S, and the expectation of m is defined as a linguistic 2-tuple E(m), where E(m) = ∆ g t=0 tβ t .

Zhang et al. [20] defined the inaccuracy degree of a balanced LDA based on the concept of information entropy. Based on this work, it is defined the normalized inaccuracy degree of a balanced LDA. Definition 8. Let m = {⟨s t , β t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} be a balanced LDA of a linguistic term set S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g }, where s t ∈ S, β t ≥ 0, t = 0, 1, . . . , g and g t=0 β t = 1. The normalized inaccuracy degree of m is defined as
div.formula: T (m) = - 1 log 2 (g + 1) g t=0 β t log 2 β t .
div.p: Subsequently, for an unbalanced linguistic term set, Dong et al. [44] defined the LDA with interval symbolic proportions. Based on Refs. [43], [44], an unbalanced LDA is defined based on the numerical scale model as follows.

Definition 9. Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } be an unbalanced linguistic term set, then m = {⟨s t , β t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} is called an unbalanced LDA of S, where s t ∈ S, β t ≥ 0 is the symbolic proportion of s t , t = 0, 1, . . . , g and
div.formula: g t=0 β t = 1. The expectation of m is defined by E(m) = N S -1 ( g t=0 β t N S(s t )).
div.p: Given a collection of LDAs, the weighted averaging operator is defined as: Definition 10. [43] Let {m 1 , m 2 , . . . , m n } be a collection of LDAs of S, where m i = {⟨s t , β i t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g}, i = 1, 2, . . . , n, and w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T be an associated weighting vector that satisfies w i ≥ 0 and n i=1 w i = 1, then the weighted averaging operator of {m 1 , m 2 , . . . , m n } is defined as DAWA w (m 1 , m 2 , . . . , m n ) = {⟨s t , β t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g}, (5) where β t = n i=1 w i β i t , t = 0, 1, . . . , g. Recently, by combing the concept of HFLTSs and LDAs, Zhang et al. [45] proposed the concept of a complete HLD and an incomplete HLD. In this paper, only the concept of a normalized complete HLD is provided.
div.formula: Definition 11. [45] Let S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set, then M = {⟨H S i , β H S i ⟩|H S i ∈ H S } is called a normalized complete HLD of S, where H S is the set of all LDA defined on S , β H S i ≥ 0 is the symbolic proportion of H S i , ∀H S i ∈ H S and H S i ∈H S β H S i = 1.
div.p: For simplicity, a normalized complete HLD is called an HLD in this paper.
div.formula: Remark 3. If S is a balanced linguistic term set, M = {⟨H S i , β H S i ⟩|H S i ∈ H S } is called a balanced HLD; if S is an unbalanced linguistic term set, M = {⟨H S i , β H S i ⟩|H S i ∈ H S } is called an unbalanced HLD.

div.head: III. REPRESENTING AN LDA BY USING AN HLD
div.p: Here it is discussed the representation of an LDA by using an HLD to provide results easy to understand.

Given a collection of LDAs, if an aggregation operator is applied, the aggregation result is also an LDA. For such an aggregation result, one question is how to provide more intuitively interpretable results for decision makers. Let us consider the following LDA m = {⟨s 0 , 0.24⟩, ⟨s 1 , 0.35⟩, ⟨s 3 , 0.15⟩, ⟨s 4 , 0.26⟩} defined on S = {s 0 , s 1 , s 2 , s 3 , s 4 }, which is obtained by some aggregation operators of LDAs. As all linguistic terms in S except s 2 have non-zero symbolic proportions, i.e., the symbolic proportions are dispersedly assigned to each linguistic term, it is difficult to have an interpretable intuitively linguistic result. One possible solution is to represent the LDA using an HFLTS which supports the linguistic distribution assessment most with an accurate constraint, see the maximum support degree model (MSDM) in [48]. In what follows, the MSDM is introduced in brief.

Let m = {⟨s t , α t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} be an LDA defined on a linguistic term set S = {s 0 , s 1 , . . . , s g }, then the HFLTS H that most supports m with an accurate constraint #(H) ≤ N is obtained by solving the following model:
div.formula: max H D(H, m) = st∈H α t s.t. #(H) ≤ N H ∈ H S , (6
div.p: where N is the maximum number of simple linguistic terms that can be used to represent m using H (also called accuracy degree of an HFLTS in [48]), H is an HFLTS defined on S such that #(H) ≤ N and D(H, m) is the degree to which H supports m.

In [48], the model ( 6) was transformed into a mixed 0-1 linear programming model. By solving the model, the HFLTS H is obtained. In what follows, an alternative method is developed to derive an HFLTS H that most supports an LDA m.
Given an N for S, the set of possible HFLTSs that can be used to represent m can be defined as
div.formula: H S N = {H ∈ H S |#(H) ≤ N, ∀s t ∈ H, α t > 0}.(7)
div.p: Remark 4. In Eq. (7), the condition ∀s t ∈ H, α t > 0 ensures that all simple linguistic terms in a possible HFLTS that is used to represent m should have a positive support degree to m. Therefore, the conditions in Eq. ( 7) are stricter than that in Eq. (6).

One can find that the number of elements in H S N are not very large. Hence, to find H, it would be enumerated all possible HFLTSs and then calculate the support degree D(H, m) for each possible HFLTS. By selecting the HFLTS with the maximum D(H, m) value, H can be determined by:
div.formula: H = arg max H∈H S N st∈H α t . (8
div.p: In the above example, if the maximum number of simple terms that are used for an HFLTS is set as N = 3, by Eq. ( 8), the HFLTS that supports m most can be obtained as H = {s 0 , s 1 } and the support degree is 0.59. However, by Eq. ( 6), the HFLTS that supports m most can be obtained as
div.formula: H = {s 0 , s 1 } or H = {s 0 , s 1 , s 2 }. Obviously, H = {s 0 , s 1 , s 2 }
div.p: should not be considered as the optimal HFLTS since the symbolic proportion of s 2 is 0. Therefore, Eq. ( 8) refines the results obtained by Eq. ( 6).

Even though either Eq. ( 6) or Eq. ( 8) can yield an HFLTS {s 0 , s 1 } to represent the LDA {⟨s 0 , 0.24⟩, ⟨s 1 , 0.35⟩, ⟨s 3 , 0.15⟩, ⟨s 4 , 0.26⟩} with an accurate constraint N = 3, one can find that the degree to which {s 0 , s 1 } supports the LDA is not quite large because the symbolic proportions in an LDA are dispersedly assigned to all linguistic terms in a linguistic term set which makes that the symbolic proportions cannot be concentrated on some successive linguistic terms, especially for an LDA obtained by the aggregation of some LDAs. In this case, some information is lost. To address this issue, it is developed a new algorithm to represent an LDA comprehensively by using an HLD, which can make full use of the linguistic information in an LDA and avoid the loss of information.

Keeping in mind that nonzero symbolic proportions should be concentrated on some consecutive linguistic terms, the proposed algorithm tries to discover a collection of HFLTSs with large support degrees to the LDA and output an HLD [45] to provide interpretable results. The basic idea is as follows. First, one can obtain an HFLTS H by Eq. ( 8). If the support degree is less than 1, all HFLTSs which contain simple linguistic terms in H are removed from H S N , and then Eq. ( 8) is employed to discover another HFLTS from H S N . Afterwards, the collective support degree is further calculated. The process is repeated until the collective support degree is equal to 1. This process has been developed in Algorithm 1 included in Appendix A of the supplementary materials.

Remark 5. For the HLD obtained by Algorithm 1, symbolic proportions are assigned to a few disjointed HFLTSs, which guarantees that the result is intuitive and does not result in information loss. Now we consider the above LDA m = {⟨s 0 , 0.24⟩, ⟨s 1 , 0.35⟩, ⟨s 3 , 0.15⟩, ⟨s 4 , 0.26⟩}.

Let the maximum number of simple terms for an HFLTS be 3, then the set of all possible HFLTSs can be generated as 8), we have that H = {s 3 , s 4 } has the largest support degree 0.41 (i.e., 0.15+0.26) to m. The collective support degree is 0.59+0.41=1. As a result, the algorithm terminates and an HLD {⟨{s 0 , s 1 }, 0.59⟩, ⟨{s 3 , s 4 }, 0.41⟩} is output to provide interpretable results for m. The meaning of the HLD {⟨{s 0 , s 1 }, 0.59⟩, ⟨{s 3 , s 4 }, 0.41⟩} can be interpreted as follows: for the LDA {⟨s 0 , 0.24⟩, ⟨s 1 , 0.35⟩, ⟨s 3 , 0.15⟩, ⟨s 4 , 0.26⟩}, there are two possible CLEs based on HFLTSs that support it most, i.e., "at most s 1 " and "at least s 3 ", the support degree of "at most s 1 " is 0.59, and the support degree of "at least s 3 " is 0.41.

div.p: To fuse multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs, it is necessary to transform them into linguistic expressions defined on the same linguistic term set. In this paper, we try to transform an unbalanced HFLTS into a balanced LDA.

Let H S (k) = {s k i , s k i+1 , . . . , s k j } be an HFLTS defined on S (k) . By Proposition 3, each s k h ∈ H S (k) can be transformed into an LDA defined on S B , i.e., m h . Considering the importance of each m h , i.e., 1/(j -i+1), these LDAs can be further aggregated into a new LDA by using the DAWA operator. The following definition is given formally. Definition 12. Let H S (k) = {s k i , s k i+1 , . . . , s k j } be an HFLTS defined on S (k) , then it can be transformed into an LDA defined on a balanced linguistic term set S B as
div.formula: m = DAWA w (m i , m i+1 , . . . , m j ),(12)
div.p: where
div.formula: m h = {⟨s B l h , 1 -β B h ⟩, ⟨s B l h +1 , β B

Once unbalanced HFLTSs are transformed into LDAs defined on a balanced linguistic term set S B , these LDAs can be aggregated by an aggregation operator and the aggregation result is also a balanced LDA. In order to provide interpretable results to decision makers who use an unbalanced linguistic term set, it is also necessary to transform a balanced LDA into an unbalanced LDA. The basic idea is as follows. First, we transform each linguistic term defined on a balanced linguistic term set into an unbalanced LDA and then aggregate these unbalanced LDAs to obtain a new unbalanced LDA. From this perspective, the first problem that needs to be solved is how to transform a balanced linguistic term into an unbalanced LDA. Proposition 4. div.head: V. MULTIATTRIBUTE LGDM BASED ON MULTIGRANULAR UNBALANCED HESITANT FUZZY LINGUISTIC INFORMATION
div.p: In order to deal with multiattribute LGDM defined in multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic contexts, a new approach is proposed. The main novelties of the proposed approach are three-fold:

• This is the first study that can manage multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs in LGDM problems, which makes decision makers provide their linguistic assessments over alternatives more flexibly. • The LDA is used as the aggregation tool to deal with the GDM problem, which can keep the maximum information elicited by decision makers and avoid the loss of information.

• The collective assessments of alternatives are represented by HLDs defined on decision makers' initial linguistic term sets to provide interpretable results. The multiattribute LGDM problem based on multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is formulated as follows.

div.head: A. Formulation of the multiattribute LGDM problem
div.p: For convenience, let I = {1, 2, . . . , n}, J = {1, 2, . . . , m} and K = {1, 2, . . . , q}.

Let A = {A 1 , A 2 , . . . , A n } be a set of alternatives, where A i is the i-th alternative, i ∈ I. In order to select the optimal alternative, a large group of decision makers d 1 , d 2 , . . . , d q provide their assessments over each alternative with respect to some attributes U = {U 1 , U 2 , . . . , U m }, where U j is the j-th attribute, j ∈ J. The weight vector of attributes is denoted by w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w m ) T , where w j is the weight of U j and m j=1 w j = 1, w j ≥ 0, j ∈ J. Due to the uncertainty of decision environment and decision makers' imprecise knowledge, the assessments provided by each decision maker are HFLTSs. Moreover, it is assumed that multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is used by different decision makers.

Without loss of generality, denote the unbalanced linguistic term set used by d k by S (k) = {s k 0 , s k 1 , . . . , s k g(k) } and the numerical scale of each linguistic term s k t is denoted by N S (k) (s k t ), t = 0, 1, . . . , g(k). Also, let x k ij be the linguistic assessment over the i-th alternative provided by the k-th decision maker with respect to the j-th attribute, and H S (k) be the set of all HFLTSs defined on S (k) , k ∈ K, then we have
div.formula: x k ij ∈ H S (k)
div.p: , i ∈ I, j ∈ J, k ∈ K. Therefore, the decision matrix of each decision maker can be denoted by
div.formula: X k = (x k ij ) n×m =      x k 11 x k 12 • • • x k 1m x k 21 x k 22 • • • x k 2m . . . . . . . . . . . . x k n1 x k n2 • • • x k nm      , k ∈ K.
div.p: For the previous LGDM problem, it is needed to obtain a solution of the optimal alternative through aggregating the assessments provided by decision makers.

div.head: B. The proposed multiattribute LGDM method
div.p: In this subsection, it is developed an approach to deal with multiattribute LGDM problems with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information with the use of LDAs. The framework of the proposed approach is demonstrated in Fig. 1. Specifically, the proposed approach consists the following processes: unification process, clustering process, aggregation and selection process and retranslation process. In what follows, these processes will be detailed. Eqs. ( 32) and ( 36)

Fig. 1. The framework of the proposed approach 1) Unification process: As HFLTSs provided by decision makers are defined on different unbalanced linguistic term sets and the LDA is used as the tool to aggregate decision makers' assessments, it is first needed to transform multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information into LDAs defined on a balanced linguistic term set. Herein, let us assume that the balanced linguistic term set be S (B) = {s B 0 , s B 1 , . . . , s B g }, which is also called the basic linguistic term set.

By Algorithm 2, each x k ij can be easily transformed into an LDA z k ij = {⟨s B t , α k ij,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g}, i ∈ I, j ∈ J, k ∈ K. After unification, each initial decision matrix X k is transformed into an LDA decision matrix, i.e.,
div.formula: Z k = (z k ij ) n×m =      z k 11 z k 12 • • • z k 1m z k 21 z k 22 • • • z k 2m . . . . . . . . . . . . z k n1 z k n2 • • • z k nm      , k ∈ K.
div.p: 2) Clustering process: For LGDM problems, it is usually necessary to cluster decision makers based on decision matrices such that decision makers in the same cluster are similar with each other while decision makers in different clusters are dissimilar with each other. In the literature, different clustering algorithms have been proposed. The fuzzy c-means clustering algorithm [49], which assigns each object with a membership degree to each cluster by calculating the distance between each object and the corresponding cluster center, is one of the most widely used algorithm to detect clusters. In this paper, an LDA-based clustering algorithm is devised based on the FCM algorithm.
The basic process of the proposed clustering algorithm can be illustrated as follows.

First, let the iteration number l be 0 and generate the cluster centers of the l-th iteration (denoted by some LDA decision matrices) randomly. Assume that the number of clusters is N and let each cluster center's decision matrix be Z r,0 = (z r,0 ij ) n×m , then the following conditions should be satisfied: z r,0 ij = {⟨s B t , β r,0 ij,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} such that g t=0 β r,0 ij,t = 1, β r,0 ij,t ≥ 0, t = 0, 1, . . . , g, i ∈ I, j ∈ j, r = 1, 2, . . . , N . After that, the membership degree to which a decision maker belongs to a cluster is calculated by Definitions 15 and 16.

Definition 15. Let Z r,l = (z r,l ij ) n×m be the cluster center matrix for the cluster C r,l at the l-th iteration , where z r,l ij = {⟨s B t , β r,l ij,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} is an LDA defined on S B , then the Minkowski distance between Z k and Z r,l is defined by
div.formula: dis(Z k , Z r,l ) = 1 mng n i=1 m j=1 |E(z k ij ) -E(z r,l ij )| λ 1/λ =   1 mng n i=1 m j=1 g t=0 t(α k ij,t -β r,l ij,t ) λ   1/λ , k ∈ K, r = 1, 2, . . . , N, (19
div.p: where λ > 0. In particular, if λ = 2, then dis(Z k , Z r,l ) is the Euclidean distance, which will be used in the LDA-based clustering algorithm.
Definition 16. Let Z k and Z r,l = (z r,l ij ) n×m be defined as before, then the membership degree to which d k belongs to the cluster C r,l at iteration l is calculated by
where b is the fuzziness degree of clusters, i.e., the larger the value of b, the fuzzier the cluster. Usually the value of b is set as 2.

Based on the membership degrees, the decision matrices of the updated cluster centers can be further calculated by Definition 17. Definition 17. Let Z k and µ(d k , C r,l ) be defined as before, then the decision matrices of the updated cluster centers are calculated as Z r,l+1 = (z r,l+1 ij ) n×m , where z r,l+1 ij = {⟨s B t , β r,l+1 ij,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} and
div.formula: β r,l+1 ij,t = q k=1 µ(d k , C r,l )α k ij,t q k=1 µ(d k , C r,l ) , t = 0, 1, . . . , g, i ∈ I, j ∈ J, r = 1, 2, . . . , N. (21
div.p: Let l = l + 1, then the membership degree to which each decision maker d k belongs to the updated cluster center C r,l can be calculated by Definitions 15 and 16. Afterwards, the variation of membership degrees between two consecutive iterations can be further calculated by
div.formula: var l = 1 N q q k=1 N r=1 |µ(d k , C r,l ) -µ(d k , C r,l-1 )|,(22)
div.p: where µ(d k , C r,l-1 ) and µ(d k , C r,l ) are the membership de- grees that d k belongs to C r,l-1 and C r,l , respectively, k ∈ K, r = 1, 2, . . . , N . If var l is larger than a predefined threshold ε, then the iteration will continue. Otherwise, the iteration will terminate and the decision maker d k will be assigned to the cluster C r such that µ(d k , C r,l ) = max r {µ(d k , C r,l )}. Based on the analysis, the LDA-based clustering algorithm is shown in Algorithm 4 and included in Appendix A of the supplementary materials.
By implementing Algorithm 4, each decision maker can be assigned to a cluster, denoted by C r , r = 1, 2, . . . , N .

3) Aggregation and selection process: After the clustering process, it is needed to aggregate decision matrices provided by decision makers into a collective one. First, we calculate the decision matrix of each cluster C r , r = 1, 2, . . . , N . For convenience, let Zr = (z r ij ) n×m be the decision matrix of the r-th cluster, where zr ij = {⟨s B t , ᾱr ij,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g}, then
div.formula: ᾱr ij,t = 1 |C r | d k ∈C r α k ij,t , t = 0, 1, . . . , g, i ∈ I, j ∈ J, r = 1, 2, . . . , N.(23)
div.p: In order to aggregate all clusters' decision matrices, it is needed to determine the weight of each cluster. In this section, a novel approach which considers both the size of each cluster and the accuracy of each cluster's decision matrix is proposed. The basic ideas are as follows: 1) If a cluster consists of more decision makers, then a larger weight should be assigned to the cluster; 2) If the accurate degree of a cluster's decision matrix is larger, then a larger weight should be assigned to the cluster.
First, the proportion of decision makers in a cluster C r is calculated by
Moreover, the inaccuracy index of the r-th cluster's decision matrix is calculated by
div.formula: Inacc r = 1 mn n i=1 m j=1 T (z r ij ) = - 1 log 2 (g + 1)mn n i=1 m j=1 g t=0 ᾱr ij,t log 2 ᾱr ij,t , r = 1, 2, . . . , N.(25)
div.p: Remark 6. In Eq. (25), T (z r ij ) denotes the inaccuracy degree of the LDA zr ij and the inaccuracy index Inacc r is the average of all T (z r ij ), i ∈ I, j ∈ J, r = 1, 2, . . . , N . It is easy to prove that Inacc r ∈ [0, 1], r = 1, 2, . . . , N . Based on each Inacc r , the normalized accuracy index of a cluster's decision matrix can be calculated by
div.formula: Acc r = 1 -Inacc r N r=1 (1 -Inacc r ) , r = 1, 2, . . . , N.(26)
div.p: By considering the proportion and normalized accuracy index of each cluster C r , a collective index can be defined by
div.formula: P A r = ηP rop r + (1 -η)Acc r , r = 1, 2, . . . , N,(27)
div.p: where η ∈ [0, 1] denotes the compromise between P rop r and Acc r , r = 1, 2, . . . , N . Based on the above analysis, a cluster with a larger collective index should be assigned a larger weight. Keeping this idea in mind, in what follows, it is proposed a proportion and normalized accuracy index induced ordered weighted averaging operator (PA-IOWA) of balanced LDAs based on the induced ordered weighted aggregation (IOWA) operator [50].
Definition 18. let Zr = (z r ij ) n×m be an LDA-based decision matrix, r = 1, 2, . . . , N , then the PA-IOWA operator of { Z1 , Z2 , . . . , ZN } is defined as
div.formula: f (⟨z 1 ij , P A 1 ⟩, ⟨z 2 ij , P A 2 ⟩, . . . , ⟨z N ij , P A N ⟩) = DAWA v (z σ(1) ij , z σ(2) ij , . . . , z σ(N ) ij ),(28)
div.p: where v = (v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N ) T is the associated weighting vector such that
div.formula: N r=1 v r = 1, v r ∈ [0, 1], and σ : {1, 2 . . . , N } → {1, 2, . . . , N } is a permutation such that P A σ(r) ≥ P A σ(r+1) , ∀r = 1, 2, . . . , N -1, i.e., ⟨z σ(r) ij , P A σ(r) ⟩ is a 2-tuple in which P A σ(r) is the r-th largest value in {P A 1 , P A 2 , . . . , P A N }.
div.p: Here, P A r is the order-inducing variable and z r ij is the argument variable.

In order to aggregate decision matrices of the clusters using the PA-IOWA operator, the key problem to be solved is how to determine the associated weighting vector v = (v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N ) T . Keeping in mind the idea that a cluster with a larger P A r value will be assigned a larger weight and motivated by the quantifier guided linguistic OWA operators [51], the weighting vector v = (v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N ) T can be determined by
div.formula: v r = Q r h=1 P A σ(h) N h=1 P A h -Q r-1 h=1 P A σ(h) N h=1 P A h , r = 1, 2, . . . , N,(29)
div.p: where Q(x) = x γ (0 < γ < 1) is a regular increasing monotone quantifier.
It is obvious that when
div.formula: Q(x) = x γ (0 < γ < 1), we have v 1 ≥ v 2 ≥ . . . ≥ v N .
div.p: Usually, when the importance of the cluster with the largest P A r value is emphasized, γ should be set as a value that approximates 0. However, when the differences of the importance among different clusters are not too large, γ can be set a value that approximates 1.

Applying the PA-IOWA operator, each cluster's LDA decision matrix can be aggregated into a collective one, which is denoted by Z = (z ij ) n×m , where zij = {⟨s B t , ᾱij,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} is an LDA derived by Definition 18, i ∈ I, j ∈ J.

Once the collective decision matrix is derived, the selection process is implemented. By applying the DAWA operator, one can aggregate the attribute values to obtain the collective assessment of each alternative.

If the weighting vector of attributes is known, the col-lective assessment of the i-th alternative, denoted by zi = {⟨s B t , ᾱi,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g}, can be calculated, where ᾱi,t = m j=1 w j ᾱij,t , t = 0, 1, . . . , g, i ∈ I. (
If the weighting vector of attributes is unknown, the maximum deviation approach proposed in [20] can be used to determine the weights, i.e.,
div.formula: w j = n i=1 n l=1 g t=0 t(ᾱ ij,t -ᾱlj,t ) n j=1 n i=1 n l=1 g t=0 t(ᾱ ij,t -ᾱlj,t ) , j ∈ J. (31
div.p: Afterwards, by Eq. ( 30), each z i can also be calculated, i ∈ I.

As each z i is an LDA which can also be considered as a discrete random variable, the dominance degree-based approach is used to rank alternatives [19]. Let p ij be the dominance degree to which A i is preferred to A j , then
div.formula: p ij = g t=0 t l=0 ᾱi,t ᾱj,l -0.5 g t=0 ᾱi,t ᾱj,t , i, j ∈ I. (32
div.p: One can prove that 0 ≤ p ij ≤ 1, p ij +p ji = 1 and p ii = 0.5, i, j ∈ I.

Based on the idea of the PROMETHEE II method [52], a popular method for ranking in multicriteria decision making, it is defined the positive outranking flow Φ + (A i ) and the negative outranking flow Φ -(A i ) of each A i as
div.formula: Φ -(A i ) = 1 n -1 j=1,j̸ =i p ji , i ∈ I. (34
div.p: Finally, the net outranking flow is calculated by calculating the difference between Φ + (A i ) and Φ -(A i ) as
div.formula: Φ(A i ) = Φ + (A i ) -Φ -(A i ), i ∈ I (35
div.p: As p ij + pji = 1, then Eq. ( 35) can be further written as
By ranking each Φ(A i ) in descending order, the ranking of alternatives can be obtained, i.e., the larger the value of Φ(A i ), the better the alternative A i .

4) Retranslation process: For an MAGDM problem with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information, if the purpose is for ranking alternatives, the procedure will terminate after ranking alternatives based on the net outranking flow of each alternative. However, for some practical decision making problems, decision makers may want to know the collective assessments over alternatives, i.e., it is necessary to provide interpretable results to decision makers. In order to do so, the collective assessments over alternatives should be retranslated to assessments defined on linguistic term sets used by each decision maker. In this paper we retranslate the collective assessments of alternatives to HLDs defined on linguistic term sets used by each decision maker.

For each decision maker d k , we can first transform each alternative's collective assessment zi = {⟨s B t , ᾱi,t ⟩|t = 0, 1, . . . , g} into an unbalanced LDA z k i defined on S (k) by Algorithm 3, i ∈ I, k ∈ K. For each z k i , the corresponding HLD H k i can be further obtained by Algorithm 1, i ∈ I, k ∈ K.
The procedure of the proposed approach is summarized below.
Step 1: Invite decision makers to provide their decision matrices X k , k ∈ K over each alternative with respect to all attributes.
Step 2: Transform all decision matrices X k into LDA decision matrices Z k by Algorithm 2.
Step 3: Use the LDA-based clustering algorithm (Algorithm 4) to cluster decision makers into N clusters {C 1 , C 2 , . . . , C N }.
Step 4: For each cluster C r , calculate its decision matrix Zr = (z r ij ) n×m by Eq. ( 23). Afterwards, calculate the value of P A r by Eqs. ( 24) -( 27), r = 1, 2, . . . , N .
Step 5: Aggregate all clusters' decision matrices into a collective one Z = (z ij ) n×m by the PA-IOWA operator.
Step 6: If the weight of attributes is known, go to Step 7;
Otherwise, use Eq. ( 31) to determine the weight vector of attributes.
Step 7: Aggregate all attribute values to obtain the collective assessments of each alternative zi by Eq. ( 30), i ∈ I.
Step 8: Rank alternatives through calculating Φ(A i ) by Eqs. ( 32) and (36), i ∈ I.

Step 9: If necessary, provide interpretable results H k i to each d k , k ∈ K, i ∈ I. In particular, for each d k , use Algorithm 3 to transform each zi into an LDA z k i defined on S (k) and then use Algorithm 1 to represent each z k i as an HLD H k i , i ∈ I, k ∈ K.

div.head: C. Comparisons and Discussions
div.p: In this subsection, the advantages of the proposed multiattribute LGDM approach are analyzed through comparisons with previous studies.
In the literature, some proposals have been devoted to deal with LGDM approach with linguistic information, which are further summarized as follows.

(1) In [18], Liu et al. proposed a two-layer weight determination method for large-scale MAGDM in linguistic environments based on the 2-tuple linguistic model. The core contribution of this study is the development of a minimized variance model and an entropy weight model to determine the expert weights in the cluster and the cluster weights, respectively. Liu et al. [19] developed an approach to LGDM in which decision makers from multiple groups were involved in the decision making problem. In this approach, a subjective and objective weighting method was proposed to determine the weights of each group and the alternatives were ranked using 1063-6706 (c) 2019 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission. See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information. This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2019.2949758, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems the dominance degree-based approach. Moreover, Zhang et al. [53] developed a method to address linguistic LGDM problems with multiple groups based on the concept of probabilistic linguistic term set. In this study, a consistency and consensusbased model was developed to objectively determine the weights of the groups, and the dominance degree-based approach was used to rank alternatives. Xiao et al. [54] developed a personalized individual semantics-based consensus model to handle LGDM problems with linguistic distribution preference relations, in which the numerical scales of each individual linguistic term set were first generated and some optimization models were then established to help decision makers reach consensus. For LGDM problems with probabilistic linguistic terms sets, Ma et al. [55] proposed an approach to model the reliability of decision makers based on evidential reasoning and the linguistic granulation optimization method.

(2) Zhang et al. [20] developed an approach to manage multigranular balanced linguistic information in multiattribute LGDM problems, in which decision makers' multigranular balanced linguistic information were first represented by multigranular balanced LDAs. To obtain the collective decision matrix, multigranular balanced LDAs were further fused based on the linguistic computational model proposed in [20]. Finally, the collective assessments of alternatives were obtained by applying the DAWA operator on the collective decision matrix. Yu et al. [40] proposed an approach to LGDM with multigranular unbalanced linguistic information, in which multigranular unbalanced linguistic information were represented by an LDA defined on a virtual linguistic term set and then the TODIM method was extended to rank alternatives by considering the psychological behavior of decision makers.

(3) Wu et al. [56] investigated linguistic LGDM problems under social network environment, in which linguistic information were first transformed into interval type-2 fuzzy sets, and then a social network analysis and TOPIS-based approach was developed to determine the weights of decision makers and to rank alternatives. and consensus in linguistic distribution large-scale group decision making Through comparison with the aforementioned studies, the proposed approach presents the following advantages.

(1) First, existing studies mainly focus on LGDM with linguistic expressions elicited by a simple linguistic term, which cannot be used to model the situations when decision makers may have some hesitancy when expressing their linguistic assessments. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study that deal with multiattribute LGDM problems with HFLTSs. Moreover, in most of previous studies, it is assumed that linguistic term sets used by decision makers to express linguistic information are balanced. However, the proposed approach can manage hesitant fuzzy linguistic information based on multigranular unbalanced linguistic term sets. As a result, the proposed approach provides a more flexible and general way for decision makers to express linguistic preferences in LGDM problems.
(2) In [20], the LDA is used as the tool to represent group assessments, which keeps the maximum information elicited by decision makers in initial stages of the decision process.

In a similar manner, this study transforms multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs into balanced LDAs, which also preserves the maximum information elicited by decision makers compared with the studies in [18], [19], [56]. Although LDAs or probabilistic linguistic terms sets are used in Xiao et al and Ma et al's approaches [54], [55], these approaches are unsuitable for the LGDM problem considered in this paper. Moreover, all these approaches [18], [19], [54]- [56] cannot be used deal with LGDM problems with multigranular or unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information. Finally, in this paper, an LDA-based clustering algorithm is developed to cluster decision makers and the PA-IOWA operator is used to aggregate linguistic distribution decision matrices of different clusters, which takes into account both the proportion of decision makers in each cluster and the accuracy index of each cluster's decision matrix and can provide more information when determining the weights of clusters.

(3) Lastly, one can find that the approaches proposed in [18], [40], [53]- [56] aim to obtain a ranking of alternatives, which cannot provide interpretable linguistic results to decision makers. However, the proposed approach represents the collective assessments of alternatives (balanced LDAs) by HLDs defined on each decision maker's initial linguistic term set, which are consisted of some disjointed HFLTSs and their support degrees to the LDAs. Therefore, the proposed approach follows the paradigm of CW, which can provide both ranking of alternatives and interpretable linguistic results to decision makers.

div.head: VI. NUMERICAL EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, a numerical example for subway line selection adapted from [57] is provided to demonstrate the proposed approach.

Suppose that the government of a city in China intends to add a new subway line to the public transportation system. After initial discussions, four alternative plans x 1 , x III. Without loss of generality, the numerical scale of each linguistic term in S (k) (k = 1, 2, . . . , 20) is the corresponding canonical characteristic value (CCV) [58], which are also shown in Tables I -III. Using these linguistic term sets, the hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrices are provided by the stakeholders as X k , k = 1, 2, . . . , 20. div.head: VII. CONCLUSISONS
div.p: In this paper, an approach to multiattribute LGDM with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is presented. The main contributions of the paper are as follows.

First, it is proposed an algorithm to represent an LDA using an HLD consisting of some disjointed HFLTSs, which can provide not only the overall assessment using some disjointed HFLTSs, but also the degree to which each HFLTS supports the LDA. Such representation offers a new way to provide intuitively interpretable results for an LDA.

Second, to facilitate the fusion of multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information, this paper develops an algorithm to transform an unbalanced HFLTS into a balanced LDA. To represent the aggregation result of multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information using the linguistic term sets used by decision makers, another algorithm is developed to transform a balanced LDA into an unbalanced LDA. The two algorithms lay good foundations for managing multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information in multiattribute LGDM problems.

Third, an approach to multiattribute LGDM with multigranular unbalanced hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is proposed. In the proposed approach, an LDA-based clustering algorithm is devised to cluster decision makers and a PA-IOWA operator is proposed to fuse each cluster's decision matrix. The collective assessments of alternatives are represented by HLDs defined on each decision maker's initial linguistic term set to provide interpretable results.
Even though this paper proposes a novel approach to multiattribute LGDM with multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs, there are still some problems which need to be further studied:

Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2019.2949758, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems 14 1) In the proposed LGDM approach, only selection process is discussed and consensus reaching process is not considered [59], [60], which plays an important role in LGDM. As a result, it is essential to study consensus reaching process for multiattribute LGDM with multigranular unbalanced HFLTSs based on the results reported in this paper.

2) The type-2 fuzzy envelope was recently proposed to depict the uncertainty and fuzziness of an HFLTS [61]. Therefore, utilizing the methodology of type-2 fuzzy sets [62]- [66] to manage multigranular HFLTSs constitutes another interesting direction for future research.

3) The proposed approach is only compared with previous studies from a theoretical perspective, since previous studies cannot deal with the same type of decision making problems and a computational comparison is not fair. Therefore, it is necessary to carry out computational comparison with recent proposals in future.
4) Finally, it is also interesting to develop a decision support system to deal with practical LGDM problems.
